misconceptions.name: Implemented average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program solves a completely different problem: it computes average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of summing the even numbers among 5 integers entered by the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to read initial and final velocities (v0, v1) and time t, compute the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t, and print that value.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even (using n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of those even numbers in a variable, and then print the sum with the required message.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Variables v0, v1, and t of type double are used instead of integer inputs.
The core computation is (v1 - v0) / t rather than summing selected inputs.
Output message is 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this assignment and a different textbook/example problem about average acceleration, leading the student to implement the wrong algorithm entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and redesign the program: initialize an integer sum to 0, use a loop to read 5 integers, for each input check if it is even with n % 2 == 0, and if so add it to sum. Finally, print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by the sum.
related_concepts: Problem decomposition from English to code
Using modulo operator for even/odd checks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names, data types, formula, and output message) matches a standard average-acceleration example and has no overlap with the required sum-of-evens algorithm.

evidence.note: This code clearly implements average acceleration from physics instead of reading 5 integers, checking evenness, accumulating a sum, and printing 'Sum of even numbers'.

misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles once instead of five integers for processing
misconceptions.description: The program reads exactly three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers that are to be processed for evenness and summed.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that the required input is three numeric values corresponding to v0, v1, and t, read with nextDouble(), matching an average-acceleration problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read 5 integer values from the user, typically using nextInt() in a loop or otherwise ensuring that exactly five integers are obtained for processing.
symptoms: Uses nextDouble() three times instead of reading five values.
No mechanism (loop or repeated calls) to obtain 5 inputs.
Variable names and count (v0, v1, t) do not correspond to 5 generic integers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about the problem requirements, likely copying or adapting from a different example that requires three double inputs instead of five integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input logic to match the specification: either call nextInt() five times or, better, use a for-loop that runs 5 times, each iteration reading one integer. Store and process each input (e.g., immediately test if it is even and add it to an accumulator).
related_concepts: Looping over a fixed number of inputs
Matching data types to problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt and the three nextDouble() calls clearly conflict with the requirement to read five integers; there is no attempt to obtain five inputs.

evidence.note: Only three inputs (v0, v1, t) are read, and all are doubles, which does not satisfy the requirement to read 5 integers from the user.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The program does not use any loop to handle multiple input values, even though the task requires processing 5 numbers, typically via a for or while loop.
misconceptions.student_belief: Reading a few values one by one without a loop is sufficient for this problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a fixed number of similar operations must be performed (such as reading and processing 5 numbers), a loop is the appropriate construct to avoid code repetition and to scale if the count changes.
symptoms: No for or while loop in the program.
Inputs are read with individual nextDouble() calls only three times.
No repeated structure for processing each of 5 numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Either the student reused a single-calculation example or has not yet internalized the pattern of using loops to process multiple similar inputs.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that iterates 5 times. In each iteration, read one integer and process it (e.g., check if it is even and update the sum).

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no loop anywhere in the code; all input and processing is done once.

misconceptions.name: No conditional logic to filter even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (e.g., using n % 2 == 0) and therefore cannot selectively sum only even numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The problem only requires computing a single arithmetic expression (acceleration), so no conditional checks are needed.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To compute the sum of only even numbers, each input must be tested with a conditional (such as if (n % 2 == 0)) before being added to the running sum.
symptoms: No if statement based on n % 2 == 0 appears in the code.
The only arithmetic performed is (v1 - v0) / t.
No separate handling of even vs. odd numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to be solving a different textbook problem (average acceleration) and never implemented the required filtering logic for even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Inside the loop that reads the 5 integers, add an if statement: if (n % 2 == 0) { sum += n; } so that only even numbers contribute to the total.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no conditional logic related to parity; the code is a straight-line computation of acceleration.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Only arithmetic is the acceleration formula; there is no conditional check like n % 2 == 0.
